subject: OOPS
question: What is Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?
expected_points: Programming paradigm based on objects
Focuses on data rather than logic
Uses classes as blueprints
Includes pillars: Encapsulation, Abstraction, Inheritance, Polymorphism
reference_answer: OOP is a programming paradigm that revolves around 'objects' rather than functions and logic. It aims to implement real-world entities like inheritance, hiding, and polymorphism in programming to make code reusable and easier to maintain.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the difference between a Class and an Object?
expected_points: Class is a blueprint; Object is an instance
Class is a logical entity; Object is a physical entity
Class doesn't occupy memory; Object does
One class can create multiple objects
reference_answer: A Class is a user-defined template or blueprint that defines the variables and methods common to all objects of a certain kind. An Object is a specific instance of a class that has its own state and behavior and occupies memory space.

subject: OOPS
question: What is Encapsulation?
expected_points: Binding data and methods together
Hiding internal details using access modifiers
Achieved using private variables and public getters/setters
Increases data security and control
reference_answer: Encapsulation is the mechanism of wrapping data (variables) and code (methods) together as a single unit. It restricts direct access to data from outside the class, which is known as data hiding, usually implemented with private fields and public methods.

subject: OOPS
question: What is Abstraction and how is it achieved?
expected_points: Hiding complex implementation details
Showing only essential features to the user
Achieved using Abstract Classes
Achieved using Interfaces
reference_answer: Abstraction is the process of hiding internal implementation details and showing only the necessary functionality to the user. In languages like Java or C++, it is achieved using abstract classes and interfaces.

subject: OOPS
question: What is Inheritance and its types?
expected_points: One class acquiring properties of another
Promotes code reusability
Types: Single, Multiple, Multilevel, Hierarchical, Hybrid
Uses 'is-a' relationship
reference_answer: Inheritance allows a new class (subclass/child) to inherit the attributes and methods of an existing class (superclass/parent). This promotes reusability. Common types include Single, Multilevel, and Hierarchical inheritance.

subject: OOPS
question: What is Polymorphism and its types?
expected_points: Ability of a message to be displayed in more than one form
Compile-time: Method Overloading
Runtime: Method Overriding
Allows objects of different types to be treated as a common type
reference_answer: Polymorphism means 'many forms'. It allows one interface to be used for a general class of actions. Compile-time polymorphism is achieved through overloading, while Runtime polymorphism is achieved through overriding.

subject: OOPS
question: What is a Constructor?
expected_points: Special method used to initialize objects
Called automatically when an object is created
Has the same name as the class
Does not have a return type
reference_answer: A constructor is a special member function of a class that initializes an object of that class. It is automatically invoked when an instance is created and usually has the same name as the class itself.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the difference between Method Overloading and Overriding?
expected_points: Overloading: Same name, different parameters in same class
Overriding: Same name and parameters in child class
Overloading is Compile-time; Overriding is Runtime
Overriding requires inheritance
reference_answer: Method Overloading happens when multiple methods have the same name but different signatures within the same class. Method Overriding occurs when a child class provides a specific implementation for a method already defined in its parent class.

subject: OOPS
question: What is an Interface in OOPS?
expected_points: Blueprint of a class containing only abstract methods
Used to achieve 100% abstraction
Supports Multiple Inheritance
Methods are typically public and abstract by default
reference_answer: An interface is a completely abstract class that only contains the declarations of methods without their implementations. It is used to achieve total abstraction and allows a class to implement multiple interfaces, bypassing multiple inheritance limitations in some languages.

subject: OOPS
question: What is an Abstract Class?
expected_points: Class declared with 'abstract' keyword
Cannot be instantiated
Can contain both abstract and concrete methods
Acts as a base for other classes
reference_answer: An abstract class is a class that cannot be instantiated on its own and may contain one or more abstract methods. It is intended to be inherited by concrete subclasses that provide implementations for the abstract methods.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the purpose of the 'static' keyword?
expected_points: Belongs to the class rather than instances
Shared among all objects of the class
Can be used with variables, methods, and blocks
Saves memory as it is allocated only once
reference_answer: The 'static' keyword indicates that a particular member (variable or method) belongs to the class itself rather than to individual instances. Only one copy of a static member exists in memory, which is shared by all objects of that class.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the 'super' keyword and when is it used?
expected_points: Used to refer to immediate parent class objects
Invokes parent class constructors
Accesses parent class methods that are overridden
Accesses parent class variables hidden by subclasses
reference_answer: 'super' is a reference variable used to refer to immediate parent class objects. It is commonly used to invoke parent class constructors, call overridden methods, or access hidden fields in the parent class.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the 'final' keyword used for?
expected_points: Final Variable: Value cannot be changed (constant)
Final Method: Cannot be overridden
Final Class: Cannot be inherited
Ensures security and performance optimization
reference_answer: The 'final' keyword is used to apply restrictions. A final variable becomes a constant, a final method cannot be overridden by subclasses, and a final class cannot be extended through inheritance.

subject: OOPS
question: What is Garbage Collection in OOPS?
expected_points: Automatic memory management process
Reclaims memory occupied by unreachable objects
Prevents memory leaks
Runs on the heap area
reference_answer: Garbage Collection is an automatic process in languages like Java or C# where the system identifies and deletes objects that are no longer reachable or used by the program, thereby freeing up memory in the heap.

subject: OOPS
question: Explain the difference between Stack and Heap memory.
expected_points: Stack: Stores local variables and function calls
Heap: Stores objects and global variables
Stack: Faster access, smaller size
Heap: Slower access, larger size, managed by GC
reference_answer: Stack memory is used for static memory allocation and execution of a thread; it stores local variables and follows LIFO. Heap memory is used for dynamic memory allocation where objects are stored and is managed by the Garbage Collector.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the 'this' keyword?
expected_points: Refers to the current class instance
Differentiates between local and instance variables
Used to call current class constructors
Can be passed as an argument in methods
reference_answer: 'this' is a reference keyword that refers to the current object. It is most commonly used to eliminate confusion between class attributes and parameters with the same name.

subject: OOPS
question: What is an Access Modifier?
expected_points: Defines the scope/visibility of classes and members
Private: Visible only within the class
Public: Visible everywhere
Protected: Visible in same package and subclasses
reference_answer: Access modifiers are keywords that set the accessibility of classes, methods, and variables. Common ones include Private (most restrictive), Public (least restrictive), and Protected (accessible to subclasses).

subject: OOPS
question: What is a Destructor?
expected_points: Method called when an object is destroyed
Used to release resources (file handles, network connections)
Named with a tilde (~) in C++
Not explicitly needed in GC-based languages like Java
reference_answer: A destructor is a special member function that is automatically called when an object goes out of scope or is explicitly deleted. Its primary purpose is to release resources held by the object before its memory is reclaimed.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the 'Finalize' method?
expected_points: Called by the Garbage Collector before an object is destroyed
Used for cleanup activities before memory reclamation
Found in Java (deprecated in newer versions)
Does not guarantee immediate execution
reference_answer: The finalize() method is a protected method defined in the Object class. It is invoked by the Garbage Collector on an object when it determines there are no more references to the object, allowing for final cleanup.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the difference between a Shallow Copy and a Deep Copy?
expected_points: Shallow Copy: Copies references to existing objects
Deep Copy: Creates new instances of all nested objects
Shallow: Faster but changes affect both copies
Deep: Slower but creates independent clones
reference_answer: A shallow copy creates a new object but inserts references to the original nested objects. A deep copy creates a new object and recursively creates new instances of all nested objects, making the two entirely independent.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the difference between an Abstract Class and an Interface?
expected_points: Abstract classes can have constructors; Interfaces cannot
Abstract classes support all access modifiers; Interfaces are implicitly public
A class can implement multiple interfaces but only extend one abstract class
Abstract classes can have member variables; Interfaces only have constants
reference_answer: An abstract class allows you to create functionality that subclasses can implement or override, while an interface only defines a contract. Abstract classes can have state (fields) and constructors, whereas interfaces are purely for defining behavior that multiple unrelated classes can share.

subject: OOPS
question: What is a Virtual Function?
expected_points: A function in a base class that can be overridden in a derived class
Used to achieve Runtime Polymorphism
In C++, declared using the 'virtual' keyword
Enables dynamic binding
reference_answer: A virtual function is a member function in a base class that you expect to redefine in derived classes. When you refer to a derived class object using a pointer to the base class, you can call a virtual function for that object and execute the derived class's version of the function.

subject: OOPS
question: What is a Pure Virtual Function and an Abstract Class?
expected_points: Function with no implementation (declared with = 0 in C++)
Forces derived classes to provide an implementation
Any class with at least one pure virtual function becomes abstract
Abstract classes cannot be instantiated
reference_answer: A pure virtual function is a function that has no body in the base class. It acts as a placeholder that must be implemented by any non-abstract derived class. A class containing such a function is an 'Abstract Class' and cannot be used to create objects directly.

subject: OOPS
question: What is a Copy Constructor?
expected_points: Member function that initializes an object using another object of the same class
Used for Shallow or Deep copying
Takes a reference to an object of the same class as an argument
Called when an object is passed by value
reference_answer: A copy constructor is a special constructor used to create a new object as a copy of an existing object. It is essential when a class manages dynamic memory to ensure that each object has its own separate copy of the resources (Deep Copy).

subject: OOPS
question: What is the difference between 'this' pointer and 'super' (or base)?
expected_points: this refers to the current object instance
super/base refers to the immediate parent class
this is used to resolve naming conflicts with parameters
super is used to call parent constructors or overridden methods
reference_answer: 'this' is a constant pointer that holds the address of the current object, allowing it to access its own members. 'super' (or 'base' in C#) is a keyword used to access members of the parent class, often to reuse logic from a parent method that has been overridden.

subject: OOPS
question: Explain Hybrid Inheritance and the Diamond Problem.
expected_points: Combination of more than one type of inheritance
Diamond Problem occurs when a class inherits from two classes that share a common base
Leads to ambiguity in method resolution
Resolved using Virtual Inheritance (C++) or Interfaces (Java)
reference_answer: Hybrid inheritance is a mix of multiple and hierarchical inheritance. The 'Diamond Problem' is a specific issue where a child class can access a base class through multiple paths, causing the compiler to get confused about which version of a method or variable to use.

subject: OOPS
question: What is a Friend Function?
expected_points: Function that is not a member but can access private/protected members
Declared inside the class with the 'friend' keyword
Does not have a 'this' pointer
Can be a global function or a member of another class
reference_answer: A friend function is a function that is granted special permission to access the private and protected parts of a class, even though it is not a member of that class. It is useful for operator overloading or bridging two different classes.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the difference between a Structure and a Class?
expected_points: Structures have default public access; Classes have default private access
Classes support inheritance; Structures (in some languages) do not
Classes are for complex objects; Structures are for data bundling
Classes are usually reference types; Structures are value types
reference_answer: The primary technical difference in languages like C++ is the default access level: public for structs and private for classes. Conceptually, structs are often used for simple data containers, while classes are used for full-featured objects with encapsulation and inheritance.

subject: OOPS
question: What is an Inline Function?
expected_points: Function where the compiler replaces the call with the actual code
Reduces function call overhead
Suggested using the 'inline' keyword
Best for small, frequently called functions
reference_answer: An inline function is a request to the compiler to insert the complete body of the function in every place that the function is called, rather than jumping to a specific memory location. This saves time but can increase the size of the final executable if overused.

subject: OOPS
question: What is the 'Static Binding' vs 'Dynamic Binding'?
expected_points: Static Binding occurs at compile-time (Method Overloading)
Dynamic Binding occurs at runtime (Method Overriding)
Static binding is faster; Dynamic binding is more flexible
Dynamic binding requires virtual functions
reference_answer: Binding refers to the link between a function call and the actual code. Static binding happens when the compiler can determine the function to call during compilation. Dynamic binding waits until the program is running to determine the call based on the actual type of the object.
